bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, January 15, 1942

div1.p: Kellogg discusses a planned series of medical portraits.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, January 15, 1942
div1.opener:
Rochester, Minnesota
January 15, 1942
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Willard Hotel
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
I have spent half of the morning and most of the
afternoon with Doctor Alvarez, and he has been of tremendous help, both on
the “Pioneers of American Medicine” series and the series on “Gastroenter-
ology.” This latter series of portraits we had planned to devote entirely
to men directly connected with the study and treatment of peptic ulcer, but
after talking with Doctor Alvarez I think that we will revise this idea and
have the series in the general field of gastroenterology. By doing this we
can keep an interesting series of pictures going out for a period of years.
If we find that the physicians like the Ernest Hamlin technique, after a
few years we should have a most unusual series of portraits which should be
bound in a booklet for general distribution to the medical profession.
I was surprised to find that Doctor Alvarez was as much interested in medical
history as he is.

I have been in to see the Hench yellow fever collec-
tion in the library here, and am delighted with it. Only one thing bothered
me and that bothers me quite a bit. When the “Cuban Version” sketches were
framed I gave the framer the copy which was to be placed on the mats and
thought that I indicated the amount of space it should occupy quite clearly.
I was amazed to see the terrifically large black lettering which he had
placed on the mats as I did not see the sketches after they had been framed
or before they were shipped to you. Perhaps you do not object to the large
size of this lettering which is certainly legible where the sketches are hang-
ing at present, but if you wish to put them in some other place I am afraid
that you will find it objectionable. Therefore, if you would care to have it
done, you might send the framed sketches to someone here in Rochester who
could remove them from the frames, make new mats and have new lettering done
which would not hit your eye quite so hard. If you would like to have this
done do not hesitate to send me the bill because we wish to do the job right.

We tried to call Mrs. Hench at the Roosevelt three
different times in the day and a half after you left, partly because we were
worried as to whether or not you made your train. She was out each time we
called and so we can only hope that we did not cause you to miss what I am
afraid was the last train that night. I am just wondering how long it is
going to take me to get over the embarrassment which I experienced when try-
ing to carve that roast. Between knowing that we were late with dinner and
-2 Dr. Philip S. Hench
January 15, 1942
my inexact knowledge as to the anatomy of the animal on which I was working,
I was more upset than you probably realized. By this time next week it will
probably be funny even to my wife. I am sitting in your office dictating
this to your pro tem secretary whom I am going to ask to sign this for me as
I am making the 5:45 plane to Chicago.

I should be ashamed to confess it, and I probably
will not have the courage to do so at home, but last night again I saw
Hildegarde. I was out with a man and his wife of the business department of
the American Medical Association who had not seen her, and so we went to the
Blackstone where she is appearing in what proved to be an entirely new
repertoire. You probably will think she is preying on my mind but I really
think both you and Mrs. Hench would have enjoyed her last night. Just to
have something to say to her you may be shocked to know that I told her that
Doctor and Mrs. Hench of the Mayo Clinic sent her their regards. So, should
you see her again, do not be surprised if she remembers your name because she
eats it up.

I hope you are having luck with Doctor Carroll's son.
I cannot imagine anyone being so uncooperative as he has been.

If the framed picture which we sent to the Willard
was broken I will be much chagrined. Occasionally one of them shipped alone
does get broken and I do not think there is anything sadder than a picture with
a broken glass.
